content.text: When we first started, the Fabric Editor has always positioned itself to be the
ideas with your team. We started humbly from an architectural rewrite to support
Bitbucket, Jira, Stride and now Confluence
, embarking on a journey to ship a common collaboration experience cross product. Today, with over
, the editor surpasses even Confluence (1.6m) and Bitbucket(1.5m) as the
after Trello, Jira Software, and Jira Platform. This is huge. People do rely on us a lot for content creation and collaboration.
Where do we go from now?
Compared to the old experience, we scored relatively equal in the customer satisfaction score. Today, we have officially surpassed TinyMCE, clocking a score of
without even all the extra functionality that the old editor provides. This is a significant milestone.

But what makes the difference between a 4 and a perfect 5? This is where delighters and an awesome user experience comes in. We want less of “Why are images not loading?” and more of “I didn’t know I could do that, that’s awesome!”. And we think that the editor is only in the beginning of the journey to make this happen.

At the end of every vision piece presentation, someone will inevitably put on the pragmatic hat and say: “So what’s the problem you’re trying to solve?”. That’s fair, considering we sometimes build cool features during Shipit or innovation week “just because”. This is why we need to understand the customer problems that our vision is going to solve. The immediate gut reaction is “research”. But instead of embarking on an epic quest to unify the
teamwork theory, there’s already plenty of existing literature that we can synthesise upon. From
, the list is countless. What we know is, there’s always an appetite to understand the universally common work journeys, across different facets of a team. So what do teams do in the context of work?
From all the existing research, we created an
to categorise and group information so that we can understand to top jobs to be done for all teams. We found that
This is by far the number one task across all teams. Roadmapping, setting goals and delivering on project outcomes is common from Software to Marketing and HR team.
Project planning - Roadmapping, goal setting, timelines, milestones, logistics and resources to complete work.
Coordinate tasks between team and project.
Manage project roadblocks - Identify, understand and remove roadblocks
Align on expectations for a project - communicating goals.
Assign work to others - Reach out to colleague, get context, assign
Work on the same file simultaneously - collaborating and editing
Meetings is the most common way to communicate, sync up and coordinate between work and who’s doing that work. This can range from a one on one to a formal presentation.
Preparing, participating, follow up and make decisions in a meeting.
Share content, in the form of documents, files, links
Work on the same file simultaneiously.
Get approval - Signoff, make decisions, pairing, updating docs.
High performing team track their work in one readily accessible place. This is then reviewed within a cadence to understand and improve on what’s working and what’s not working.
Track productivity, tracing history, delivery on stakeholder commitments, view remaining work
Manage project roadblocks - Identify, understand, and remove roadblocks.
Reading content and get up to date to what everyone is working on.
Align on expectations for a project by communicating expectations
Create and modify trackers and contents.

Every team needs to work towards a common goal. On the way to get there, there is a need for every individual contributor to provide ideas, resolve issues, and acknowledging the efforts and outputs of team members.
Request, provide, receive and manage feedback.
Work on the same file simultaneously.

Focus work of individual contributors is crucial to how performant a team is. Individuals within a team is also often times found engaging independent and creative thoughts to the more “admin” like activities like sorting out personal plan or transferring knowledge to a colleague.
Personal organisation - Taking notes, personal task, prioritisation, time management
Feedback - Request, provide, manage personal feedback, growth plan
Transfer knowledge - Write documentations and plans, collect relevant documentations, work handoff
Task reminders - Send and receive reminders.
Digest information - Reading content, understanding context
6. Need to do some maintenance work
Maintenance work spans the more invisible work around making sure information is organised and accessible to everyone who needs to know a particular aspect work.
Make information easy to find and readable - organise information, manage access to info so it’s easy to search
Make projects deliverables professional / attractive - Formatting and designing content and presentations
Documentation - Create or modify content, handoff work.
See the full synthesis results in a Mural board here:
Where does the editor fit in?
We believe that when it comes to the editor, we help teams perform by excelling at the three fundamental themes: helping teams connect, capture work, and express themselves.
The editor helps users to express their thoughts and ideas in various mediums across our products. Any content can be expressed in different views, fit for a wide variety of context.
E.g. from post-its to roadmap, from table to issues, a page to slides.
The editor is the place to capture all types of work. This can then be referenced and created through a familiar experience regardless of products and space.
E.g. actions, decisions, create Jira issue from everywhere, search and pick links in 3rd party provider.
The editor connects different teams together and make it possible to collaborate in a single place to move work forward, regardless of tools or boundaries.
E.g. collab editing across languages, mentions, inline comments

Slash command is arguably one of our biggest differentiators. It allows quick insertion of content and is deeply integrated to 3rd party extensions in the market. This allows users to quickly and effectively express their ideas in the document.

We repeatedly hear the close integration between Jira and Confluence is the reason why people choose our product suite. Being able to insert a JQL generated table is powerful. Automatically linked Confluence pages in an issue also saves time. The editor powers this cross flow and unlocks even more potential by leveraging the strengths in our product.

Mentions, actions, decisions, and other elements are optimised for helping teams to collaborate and move work forward. Standard rich text editors like Google Docs, Pages, Evernote doesn’t even provide this ability.
Presentation mode - OKR table every townhall
Smart link - embed and hover state (amplitude)
New inline node → Bits (capture live data, e.g.: =NASDAQ:TEAM=, or =Atlassian-eMAU=)
Better Page properties macro → Roll up of information.
1) So long static content, hello dynamic data

The story begins with the founders of a company detailing the new, refreshed plan for the year forward. After months of working hard and finalising on the company objective and key results, the leadership team is finally ready to summarise it all in a
. The dream is to make this 100% transparent to teams and employees, making sure that everyone can openly see the accurate reflection of the past and the future.

Communicating this game plan in the right way is important to set the tone for how teams work. This process typically takes months to prepare. You’d need to scramble to get an update from all teams, pull the right metrics, and finally put everything together into a Confluence page and then a Keynote presentation. That’s a lot of hard work. What if the editor can help streamline this process?
What if the founders can track the most up-to-date objectives through one single table, which can then transform seamlessly for a presentation?
Here’s how CEOs can present their source of truth in
